The Buddha said:

Bodhisattvas should cultivate eight dharmas in order to attain the Dharma of mastery and head towards mastery.
What are the eight?

First, speaking beautiful and good words with a sincere mind; second, always having a gentle mind; third, always having a loving mind; fourth, always having an impartial mind; fifth, being without flattery; sixth, being without deception; seventh, being without jealousy; eighth, always having a well-regulated mind.
If bodhisattvas possess these eight dharmas, they will attain the Dharma of mastery and progress towards mastery.
King Ajatashatru further addressed the Buddha, saying:
What dharmas should bodhisattvas cultivate in order to abide in mastery?
The Buddha said:
Great King!
Bodhisattvas should cultivate four dharmas in order to abide in mastery.
What are the four?
First, if born among humans, they wish to be a wheel-turning sage king and encounter a Buddha appearing in the world.
Second, they wish to be Shakra and encounter a Buddha appearing in the world.
Third, they wish to be the great Brahma king, lord of the Saha world, and encounter a Buddha appearing in the world.
Fourth, they wish to be a powerful and eminent householder and encounter a Buddha appearing in the world.
If bodhisattvas possess these four dharmas, they can abide in mastery.

Great King!

The king said:

The Buddha said:

The king said:

The Buddha said:

The king said:

Thus it should be known that as the Buddha has said, whether the Buddha appears in the world or not, the dharmas always abide, namely the nature of dharmas, the realm of dharmas, the abiding of dharmas, the ultimate reality, and the purity of dharmas, because the dharmas are thus.
As it is said, the dharmas that arise from conditions are also not contradictory.
Because the dharmas that arise from conditions are not contradictory, they are the true Dharma.
Because of the true Dharma, it is not obscured.
Such a teaching is called the true Dharma.

Furthermore, good man!

Moreover, within the dharma of non-abiding, there is no coming out and no entering. One transcends all defiled dharmas, and thus one attains eloquence.

From where does it come, and from where does it enter? In the middle, where does it abide? Because there is no abiding in written words, there is no coming out and going to any direction.
Moreover, because written words are not combined, there are no written words that can be recorded and explained, and it is not without explanation, without increase, and without decrease.
Because there are no written words, there is no dharma that can be discriminated as existent or nonexistent.
Because there are no written words, there is no dharma that can be produced, no dharma that can cease, no dharma that can be accomplished, and no dharma that can be destroyed.
Know, Silent Wisdom, that such written words and calculations are precisely the calculations of the mind.
As the mind calculates, so do all dharmas calculate.
As all dharmas calculate, so it is not calculation.
Why is it so?
Because dharmas cannot be obtained through calculation.
Because there is no method of counting that can count, therefore all dharmas cannot be counted.

Thus one is able to follow and enter the characteristics of dharmas, originally like this, following and entering non-arising. If one enters non-arising, there is also no arising. This is because there is not even a little dharma that can be entered. Therefore, all dharmas are without entry but enter.
Tranquil Wisdom!
If one is able to enter all calculations in this way, then one will not be able to cut off eloquence.
Why is this?
Because the nature of dharmas is without cutting off.
If one penetrates in this way, then one will be able to expound the Dharma for others as appropriate, and whatever is expounded will be realized in the present moment.
Because one follows and enters the characteristics of dharmas in this way, one thus follows and enters the characteristics of sentient beings.
Because one follows and enters the characteristics of sentient beings, one then skillfully expounds all dharmas according to one's faith and understanding.
